**Total requests:** 24,252,746
**Requests Per Minute:** 16.8k

**Percentage of POST Operations:** 5.01% 
Requests Per Minute: 0.84k

Both `/static/` and `/media` are behind a CDN.

Note that these number are before the migration to the third party. Today we are experiencing noticeable reduction in traffic due to the migration and rollback. I filed [bug 1431635](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1431635) to get more recent logs to analyze

issues.title: Search as you type is too aggresive
issues.body:
Search as you type in the default search box starts searching for documents from the first character which results in higher App and ElasticSearch use with questionable gains. 

Change the code so that it requires at least X number of characters to be typed and/or increase the wait time between the last pressed key to start of the search. Ideally make those variables configurable in the settings so we can experiment to find the best UX / Infra cost fraction.

issues.title: Search Architecture
issues.body:
* Kitsune uses ElasticSearch v2.4
* On AWS Kitsune will run on multiple regions
* ElasticSearch data don't have to be persistent and can be regenerated completely from database.

## Architecture (second iteration)

Our elastic search provider (elastic.co) creates instances with public IPs. Therefore instead of having the region local App instances update only the region local ES instance and signal the other App regions to do the same, each App instance can directly update all ES instances.

The update of ES each triggered by Django's `post_save` signals, so for example 

**when a new Document gets saved in Frankfurt**
 1. Kitsune Fra connects to RDS Oregon and saves the doc in database
 2. Kitsune Fra creates 3 Celery jobs to update that document in ES indices, one for ES running in Fra, one for ES in Oregon and one for ES in Tokyo.

issues.title: Database Architecture
issues.body:
- Kitsune uses MySQL (See #2937) on SCL3.
 - On AWS Kitsune will running in multiple regions
 - Since all visitors can potentially write on the database (from the simple task to subscribe to a question to the more complex editing and managing of KB articles), we can't have an admin only domain as we do with other apps. We want visitors on `support.mozilla.org` to be able to write to database and thus we need a database solution which supports writes from multiple locations. 
 - Recently AWS announced Aurora Multi Master support. Aurora is MySQL compatible so we could "just switch" with the downside of getting more locked-in into AWS.  Either way Aurora only supports multi-AZ Multi Master at the moment (2018-01-15) with a plan to support multi-Region in the future. We can re-eval when multi-Region becomes available but for the time being we need an alternative plan.

## Suggested Database Architecture:

 - Replication in RDS using MariaDB is known to work well. 
 - The Arch defines:
   - A DB in **Oregon** as the **Master** database
   - Databases in  **other regions** (currently Frankfurt and Tokyo) as **Read Replicants** of the Master database
 - Kitsune instances in **all regions** use [django-multidb-router](https://github.com/jbalogh/django-multidb-router) in **Pinning Mode** to route write db operations to **Oregon** while read operations get routed to the nearest Read Replica.
 - We need a secure tunnel between Oregon and other regions, using Inter-Region VPC Peering where supported or other method where not supported.

![prod after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/584352/34943770-bc5a3e8a-fa05-11e7-9ed8-1b8667413846.jpg)


### Pre AWS Migration - Development Architecture

 - To develop and test the architecture we want to setup a minimal version with a Master Database in Oregon and a Read Replica in Frankfurt.
 - The Master Database will get populated with a recent anonymized SQL dump. Ideally we want to copy what we have now in `sumo-dev` database in Frankfurt.
 - The secure tunnel between Frankfurt and Oregon needs to be established
 - After completing AWS migration this infra will be shutdown and Kitsune dev instances will switch to using the RDS instances defined in the next section.

![dev](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/584352/34943422-42843f12-fa04-11e7-9a40-f2b71efa877a.jpg)
 

### Pre AWS Migration - Production and Staging Architecture
 
 - SUMO database in big and takes some time to get imported #2993 
 - To reduce the time needed to migrate from SCL3 to AWS we're working on getting Data Replication going between the two datacenters #3006 
 - The Arch defines:
   - An RDS instance in Oregon which acts as Read Replica of SCL3
   - Two RDS instances in Frankfurt and Tokyo that act as Read Replicas of Oregon Read Replica
 - When it's time to flip the switch to AWS, Oregon will become Master and the other DBs will remain Read Replicas
 - Bonus points if we setup SCL3 to become Read Replica of AWS,  as a fallback plan.
 - We want to setup all three DBs (Oregon, Fra, Tokyo) from now so we can host a Read Only version of the site as soon as possible.
 - We also want to setup the tunnel  between Fra, Tokyo and Oregon asap, so it's ready to accept connections when Oregon becomes master.

![prod](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/584352/34944035-b0388296-fa06-11e7-81e3-71445bf850a3.jpg)

Questions:
 - Can we use MariaDB over MySQL and still get replication from SCL3 to AWS to work?
 - How we setup the tunnel between the Regions?
 
What do you think @mozilla/sumo ?

issues.title: Test READ_ONLY Mode of Kitsune in SCL3 and AWS
issues.body:
Kitsune sports a READ_ONLY mode. Test and verify that it's working as advertised. 

This will be used during the migration:

 - Both SCL3 and AWS will be switched to READ_ONLY
 - Gradually we'll shift the traffic to AWS.
 - After AWS stabilizes we'll enable writes again

- [ ] Verify that READ_ONLY in SCL3 works
- [ ] Verify that READ_ONLY in AWS works

issues.title: Switch user media to s3 + CDN on SCL3
issues.body:
We want to convert legacy codebase running on SCL3 to use S3.

See also #2899 

Deployment for staging
- [x] Rsync user media to S3 (see #2948)
- [x] Backup virtualenv and settings_local.py
- [x] Update settings_local.py
- [x] Chief push
- [x] Verify that uploads and resizing work by uploading to https://support.allizom.org/en-US/gallery/images
- [x] Verify that media CDN works
- [x] Update `Document.html` (see snippet bellow) to get the new cdn urls.
- [x] Re-run rsync to make sure that we didn't miss any uploads meanwhile

Deployment for prod
- [x] Rsync user media to S3 (see #2948)
- [x] Backup virtualenv and settings_local.py
- [x] Update settings_local.py
- [x] Chief push
- [x] Verify that uploads and resizing work by uploading to https://support.allizom.org/en-US/gallery/images
- [x] Verify that media CDN works
- [x] Update `Document.html` (see snippet bellow) to get the new cdn urls.
- [x] Re-run rsync to make sure that we didn't miss any uploads meanwhile

Note that the current CDN (support.cdn.mozilla.net) serves both user media and static media and should remain active until we complete the prod migration. We *must not* make any changes to the current CDN meanwhile.

Env Variables to update
```
    AWS_S3_CUSTOM_DOMAIN
    AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
    AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
    AWS_STORAGE_BUCKET_NAME
    AWS_S3_HOST
    MEDIA_URL
```

issues.title: Calculate time needed to restore production database
issues.body:
The production database is a large (~100Gb). We need to calculate the time needed to restore it in the real database engine that's going to be used in AWS.

If the time needed is above the threshold considered acceptable to do the move we should investigate other options, like incremental import of data. 

A dev import into a `db.t2.small` instance took about 30 hours. FTR the complete lithium migration took about 48 hours.

issues.title: Meta Issue For Docker Install On Mac
issues.body:
Parking lot for issues I am having getting the install running on mac.

### docker-compose Version Not Supported
3.4 does not appear to be supported by the version of docker I have installed (Version 17.09.0-ce-mac35, no update available). 3.3 does work

### Missing Install Docs
We don't have install docs for docker.

### What I have done thus far...
1. Change version in docker-compose file to 3.3
2. Run ```docker-compose up``` 
3. Made and drank a cup of tea.
4. Copy ```.env-dist``` to ```.env```
5. docker exec into kitsune container and run the following:
    - ```./manage.py migrate```
    - ```./manage.py createsuperuser```
    - ```./manage.py generatedata```

After the above got errors for all static content, example ```web_1            | ValueError: The file 'build/common-min.js' could not be found with <kitsune.sumo.storage.SumoFilesStorage object at 0x7f3471785fd0>.```

Tried running collect static within container.. generates error ```AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'strip'```

Stuck here for now, also tried this on my linode Linux machine..ran into the same problems.

issues.title: Improve Travis Build Time
issues.body:
Travis needs 15-20 minutes to complete testing a pull request. We need to improve this time to iterate faster.

Half of the time is spend re-building the image. Current docker version in Travis (17.03) does not support the `cache_from` directive in `docker-compose.yml` so we need to find another way to use pre-built docker images

issues.title: Fix search related tests
issues.body:
The ElasticSearch upgrade to V2 broke a number of tests.

Currently all search related tests are marked as `search_tests` and get skipped in the test runs with `-a '!search_tests'`.

This issue tracks the update / re-write of those tests to work with current infra.

See also #2931

issues.body: Kitsune has ZenDesk related code which is very possible to be deprecated. Evaluate it's usefulness and remove if not used.

issues.title: Remove TokenLogin Backend and Middleware
issues.body:
In `settings.py` there's a [TokenLogin backend](https://github.com/mozilla/kitsune/blob/master/kitsune/settings.py#L516) in addition to the Model Backend for authetication. It appears that since [bug 921480](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=921480) are not using this in production. According to the bug this was somehow related to Persona Authentication.

Since this is not in use in production, we don't need to have the code laying around. I'll remove from default settings and this issue tracks it's removal from code.

issues.title: Setup prod hosting of static media for AWS prod

milestone.title: AWS Migration
milestone.description: Things that must be done specifically for the migration.

issues.body:
For dev we'll probably just serve static media from the primary docker container via [whitenoise](http://whitenoise.evans.io/en/stable/), but that won't scale to prod traffic. We have some options:

* Sync static files to S3 and serve via a CDN
* Deploy a separate Nginx container for serving said files, optionally with a CDN in front
* Put a CDN in front of the entire site (potentially a lot more work)

issues.title: Rsync user media from SCL to S3
Switch Celery Broker to Redis
issues.body:
Currently we use RabbitMQ as the Celery broker. Celery officially supports Redis too which makes more sense to use since we already have a running Redis instance.

Redis need to be configured to not evict any keys from the Celery database so we don't have missing jobs.

commit.message: Use PATH instead of ENTRYPOINT for virtualenv activation

Add cache to app volume to improve performance on OSX. See:

https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/osxfs-caching/

[bug 1388942] Add snowball analyzer in document mapping.

searches that use it. This change brings Wiki Document mappings in part with
Question mappings which already define the analyzer.

[fix bug 1381436] Replace ES facets with DB queries. (#2886)

* [fix bug 1381436] Replace ES facets with DB queries.

ElasticSearch v2 has deprecated facets in favor of aggregations. To upgrade to
aggregations we need to update elastic search python libraries. This is a
combination of ES and Database queries to serve as a workaround until we move
codebase to v2.

Since the DB is quite slower compared to ES, the results get cached for 15
minutes.

HTTPSify links

Where possible, use https or hardcoded links (these http URLs mostly result in 301 redirect anyway).

Auto merge of #2837 - mythmon:no-lockdown, r=rehandalal

Remove vestiges of lockdown. It isn't used in prod.

Lockdown is only serving today to make our CI fail very often. I think the output of the NPM registries it proxies has changed. Additionally, it hasn't had an update in over a year, so I don't expect this problem to get fixed upstream.

Additionally, we aren't even verifying these hashes in prod. They only make CI more complex. I think we should remove them.

@rehandalal thoughts? r?

Did you remember to set migrate-helpfulvotes = true in waffle? I purposely set it that way so that it wouldn't start running before we wanted it to. We can flip it around if you'd prefer.

The way I was envisioning the push going was (based on the issues we faced last week with migrations/db errors):

waffle hide-vote = true
run migration
push code
waffle hide-vote = false
set cron to run wiki/cron.py:migrate_helpfulvotes once every 15mins
waffle migrate-helpfulvotes = true

The hide-vote waffle flag should disable anything relating to votes (so not even has_voted get's called), so we're free to let the migrations propagate.

Things I noticed immediately:
- `/contributors` can't ever crash. Right now it fails if the correct Redis backend isn't there. It can't crash then, or if the Redis server is unavailable, or if the data is gone or bad, or...
- The cron should warn you if the redis backend is undefined, or redis is down, or... That one should crash, usefully and loudly.
- Things need to be much prettier if the data is unavailable. In any of those "don't crash" situations, or whatever, we should either hide the "unhelpful" section or show something else.

stdlib

I would be strict. I would say don't indent HTML within template syntax, since the final output would be HTML so that indentation should be preserved propperly. e.g.: ```
{% if 1 %}

hi

{% endif %}
``` will render as:

hi

which is what you want.

I don't think it matters what the output looks like(1).  What I care about is readability, and we should use indentation to show our template structure, just like in Python.  I'll put `{% cache xxx %}{% for x in xxx %}` at the same nesting level since they're usually wrapped right around each other, but I think most ifs and fors deserve proper nesting.

(1): Except that we're throwing around a lot of whitespace, but that's what gzip is for.
The goal isn't to make it easier for me. The goal is to quietly enforce the standard for everyone. cf https://developer.mozilla.org/En/Mozilla_Coding_Style_Guide#Mode_Line

I'm using the UTF8 database, and seeing empty summaries, because the `excerpt` output is not a unicode string. So `wc.excerpt()` needs to be wrapped in `smart_unicode` (since Sphinx is not smart enough to return Unicode strings). Might be safe to keep the current wrap on `*.data`, but I didn't see any problems with the line I'm including below. This shows the summaries properly:
`excerpt = smart_unicode(wc.excerpt(wiki_page.data, q))`

review_comments.body:
I should probably add a more detailed comment for this, let me see if I can phrase what I was thinking...

We want to include all revisions that aren't reviewed or are reviewed and approved (those that aren't explicitly rejected). The way this is written right now the revision we are approving right now comes back in this query. To get them, I `.exclude` rejected revisions which are those that are reviewed (`reviewed__isnull=False`) and not approved (`is_approved=False`). But if there is a less confusing way to write this, that would be great.

@@ -1,16 +1,72 @@
+"""
+About our little nonce dance
+----------------------------
+
+We don't want anybody to be able to impersonate anybody else in a chat. Thus,
+we have to map a socketio SID to a user. To do that, we have to map a socketio
+SID to a session ID, which in turn can show the server that we are who we claim
+(since session ID is secret). So, when we draw the chat page, we make up a
+nonce and stick it in there, while simultaneously mapping it to the session ID
+in redis for a short time. The JS yanks the nonce out of the page and sends it
+back to the server on join, along with the socketio SID (implicitly), thus
+completing the SID-to-session-ID mapping. And, because we avoid sticking the
+session ID in the page, we avoid the possibility of session hijacking by any JS
+that gets injected by an XSS attack; cookies are protected from evil JS better
+(through HttpOnly, for example).
+
+
+About the protocol
+------------------
+
+There are several kinds of message which go flitting between the clients and
+server. Each message is a JSON dict with one or more of the fields `kind` and
+`message`.
+
+    Join. Sent from the client to the server.
+        kind: join
+        room: ID of the room to join
+
+    Leave. Sent from the client to the server to unsubscribe from a room.
+        kind: leave
+        room: ID of the room
+
+    Say. Sent in both directions.
+        kind: say
+        room: ID of the room
+        message: What was said
+
+There's no facility for private messages yet, but it can be added if needed. At
+the moment, the plan is to implement private help sessions by first creating a
+public room behind the scenes. That will allow additional moderators to steal
+into the room undetected.
+
+"""
+import json
+from string import ascii_letters
+import random
+
 from django.conf import settings
 from django.core.cache import cache
 from django.http import HttpResponse
 from django.views.decorators.cache import never_cache
 from django.views.decorators.http import require_GET
 
+from gevent import Greenlet
 import jingo
+from redis import Redis

+"""No actual Django models, but some generic ones"""
+
+import json
+import random
+
+from django.contrib.auth.models import AnonymousUser, User
+
+from gevent import Greenlet
+
+from chat import log, redis, nonce_key
+
+
+class NamedAnonymousUser(AnonymousUser):
+    """A user not mapped to a known persistent user but having a name for
+    display purposes"""
+    def __init__(self, username):
+        self.username = username
+
+
+class RoomsUserIsIn(object):
+    """A collection of rooms a user is listening to (and able to talk to).
+
+    This is the model, and the socketio view is the controller.
+
+    About the protocol:
+
+        There are several kinds of message which go flitting between the
+        clients and server. Each message is a JSON dict having the keys listed
+        below:
+
+        Join. Sent from the client to the server.
+            kind: join
+            room: ID of the room to join
+            user: Username of user joining (sent toward client only)
+
+        Leave. Sent in both directions.
+            kind: leave
+            room: ID of the room
+            user: Username of user leaving (sent toward client only)
+
+        Say. Sent in both directions.
+            kind: say
+            room: ID of the room
+            message: What was said
+            user: Username of user speaking (sent toward client only)
+
+        Nonce. Identify the user to the server by sending a nonce value.
+            kind: nonce
+            nonce: the nonce
+
+    There's no facility for private messages yet, but it can be added if
+    needed. At the moment, the plan is to implement private help sessions by
+    first creating a public room behind the scenes. That will allow additional
+    moderators to steal into the room undetected.
+
+    """
+    def __init__(self):
+        # Hanging onto these greenlets might keep them from the GC:
+        self._subscribers = {}  # room -> subscriber greenlet
+
+        # Start anonymous. JS will immediately authenticate and fix that if the
+        # user is logged in.
+        self._user = NamedAnonymousUser(self._random_nick())
+
+    def __contains__(self, room):
+        return room in self._subscribers
+
+    def _random_nick(self):
+        """Return a fun random name to distinguish anonymous users memorably.
+
+        This will go away once we get UI for entering a name.
+
+        """
+        syllables = ['nox', 'frot', 'gos', 'ler', 'jam', 'rip', 'kap']
+        return ''.join(random.choice(syllables) for _ in xrange(3))
+
+    def _send(self, room, **kwargs):
+        """Throw a JSON-coded message (from kwargs) at a room.
+
+        ...regardless of whether you're in the room.
+
+        """
+        redis().publish(room, json.dumps(kwargs))
+
+    def join(self, room, io):
+        """Start listening to a room."""
+        if room not in self:  # No joining a room twice.
+            # Start a new subscriber. At least as a starting point, we start a

+            # would be a mess of de-duping as we fight with the race of killing
+            # the old subscriber and starting a new one that listens to all
+            # joined rooms.
review_comments.body:
This seems like overkill to have a redis connection for each channel I am listening to. The pubsub messages include the originating channel so it should not be hard to sort them out.

I guess that is why you have this comment though?

Oooooooh I just realized we haven't updated our redispy version... With latest there is a separate [pubsub client](https://github.com/andymccurdy/redis-py/blob/master/redis/client.py#L1142) for doing the pub sub stuff. You should be able to use the same instance to subscribe to more channels while listening. 

See also: https://github.com/rlr/django-gevent-socketio-redis-chat-example/blob/master/chatproject/apps/chatapp1/views.py#L17

+                    'WHERE created <= DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 1 MONTH) '
+                    'AND created >= DATE_SUB(DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), '
+                        'INTERVAL 1 MONTH), INTERVAL 1 MONTH) '
+                ') as limitedvotes '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_revision ON '
+                'limitedvotes.revision_id=wiki_revision.id '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_document ON '
+                'wiki_document.id=wiki_revision.document_id '
+            'WHERE wiki_document.locale="en-US" '
+            'GROUP BY doc_id '
+            'HAVING no > yes '
+            ') as calculated ')
+
+    old_data = cursor.fetchall()
+
+    for data in old_data:
+        doc_id = data[0]
+        yes = float(data[1])
+        no = float(data[2])
+        total = yes + no
+        if total == 0:
+            continue
+        old_formatted[doc_id] = {'total': total,
+                                 'percentage': yes / total}
+
+    return old_formatted
+
+
+def _get_current_unhelpful(old_formatted):
+    final = {}
+    cursor = connection.cursor()
+
+    cursor.execute('SELECT doc_id, yes, no '
+        'FROM '
+            '(SELECT wiki_revision.document_id as doc_id, '
+                'SUM(limitedvotes.helpful) as yes, '
+                'SUM(NOT(limitedvotes.helpful)) as no '
+            'FROM '
+                '(SELECT * FROM wiki_helpfulvote '
+                    'WHERE created >= DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 1 MONTH) '
+                ') as limitedvotes '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_revision ON '
+                'limitedvotes.revision_id=wiki_revision.id '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_document ON '
+                'wiki_document.id=wiki_revision.document_id '
+            'WHERE wiki_document.locale="en-US" '
+            'GROUP BY doc_id '
+            'HAVING no > yes '
+            ') as calculated ')
+
+    current_data = cursor.fetchall()
+
+    for data in current_data:
+        doc_id = data[0]
+        yes = float(data[1])
+        no = float(data[2])
+        total = yes + no
+        if total == 0:
+            continue
+        percentage = yes / total
+        if doc_id in old_formatted:
+            final[doc_id] = {
+                'total': total,
+                'currperc': percentage,
+                'diffperc': percentage - old_formatted[doc_id]['percentage']
+            }
+        else:
+            final[doc_id] = {
+                'total': total,
+                'currperc': percentage,
+                'diffperc': 0.0
+            }
+
+    return final
+
+
+@cronjobs.register
+def cache_most_unhelpful_kb_articles():
+    """Calculate and save the most unhelpful KB articles in the past 7 days."""

+    get a percent change.
+    """
+
+    old_formatted = {}
+    cursor = connection.cursor()
+
+    cursor.execute('SELECT doc_id, yes, no '
+        'FROM '
+            '(SELECT wiki_revision.document_id as doc_id, '
+                'SUM(limitedvotes.helpful) as yes, '
+                'SUM(NOT(limitedvotes.helpful)) as no '
+            'FROM '
+                '(SELECT * FROM wiki_helpfulvote '
+                    'WHERE created <= DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 1 MONTH) '
+                    'AND created >= DATE_SUB(DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), '
+                        'INTERVAL 1 MONTH), INTERVAL 1 MONTH) '
+                ') as limitedvotes '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_revision ON '
+                'limitedvotes.revision_id=wiki_revision.id '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_document ON '
+                'wiki_document.id=wiki_revision.document_id '
+            'WHERE wiki_document.locale="en-US" '
+            'GROUP BY doc_id '
+            'HAVING no > yes '
+            ') as calculated ')
+
+    old_data = cursor.fetchall()
+
+    for data in old_data:
+        doc_id = data[0]
+        yes = float(data[1])
+        no = float(data[2])
+        total = yes + no
+        if total == 0:
+            continue
+        old_formatted[doc_id] = {'total': total,
+                                 'percentage': yes / total}
+
+    return old_formatted
+
+
+def _get_current_unhelpful(old_formatted):
+    """Gets the data for the past month and formats it as return value."""
+
+    final = {}
+    cursor = connection.cursor()
+
+    cursor.execute('SELECT doc_id, yes, no '
+        'FROM '
+            '(SELECT wiki_revision.document_id as doc_id, '
+                'SUM(limitedvotes.helpful) as yes, '
+                'SUM(NOT(limitedvotes.helpful)) as no '
+            'FROM '
+                '(SELECT * FROM wiki_helpfulvote '
+                    'WHERE created >= DATE_SUB(CURDATE(), INTERVAL 1 MONTH) '
+                ') as limitedvotes '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_revision ON '
+                'limitedvotes.revision_id=wiki_revision.id '
+            'INNER JOIN wiki_document ON '
+                'wiki_document.id=wiki_revision.document_id '
+            'WHERE wiki_document.locale="en-US" '
+            'GROUP BY doc_id '
+            'HAVING no > yes '
+            ') as calculated ')
+
+    current_data = cursor.fetchall()
+
+    for data in current_data:
+        doc_id = data[0]
+        yes = float(data[1])
+        no = float(data[2])
+        total = yes + no
+        if total == 0:
+            continue
+        percentage = yes / total
+        if doc_id in old_formatted:
+            final[doc_id] = {
+                'total': total,
+                'currperc': percentage,
+                'diffperc': percentage - old_formatted[doc_id]['percentage']
+            }
+        else:
+            final[doc_id] = {
+                'total': total,
+                'currperc': percentage,
+                'diffperc': 0.0
+            }
+
+    return final
+
+
+@cronjobs.register
+def cache_most_unhelpful_kb_articles():
+    """Calculate and save the most unhelpful KB articles in the past month."""
+
+    REDIS_KEY = settings.HELPFULVOTES_UNHELPFUL_KEY
+
+    old_formatted = _get_old_unhelpful()
+    final = _get_current_unhelpful(old_formatted)
+
+    if final == {}:
+        return
+
+    def _mean(vals):
+        """Argument: List of floats"""
+        if len(vals) == 0:
+            return None
+        return sum(vals) / len(vals)
+
+    def _bayes_avg(C, m, R, v):
+        # Bayesian Average
+        # C = mean vote, v = number of votes,
+        # R = mean rating, m = minimum votes to list in topranked
+        return (C * m + R * v) / (m + v)
+
+    mean_perc = _mean([float(final[key]['currperc']) for key in final.keys()])
+    mean_total = _mean([float(final[key]['total']) for key in final.keys()])
+
+    #  TODO: Make this into namedtuples

+"""
+Deployment for SUMO in production.
+
+Requires commander (https://github.com/oremj/commander) which is installed on
+the systems that need it.
+"""
+
+import os
+import sys
+
+sys.path.append(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)))
+
+from commander.deploy import task, hosts, hostgroups
+
+import commander_settings as settings
+
+
+@task
+def update_code(ctx, tag):
+    with ctx.lcd(settings.SRC_DIR):
+        ctx.local("git fetch -t")
+        ctx.local("git checkout -f %s" % tag)
+        ctx.local("git submodule sync")
+        ctx.local("git submodule update --init --recursive")
+        ctx.local("python2.6 manage.py compress_assets")
+
+
+@task
+def update_locales(ctx):
+    with ctx.lcd(os.path.join(settings.SRC_DIR, 'locale')):
+        ctx.local("svn up")
+        ctx.local("./compile-mo.sh .")
+
+
+@task
+def schematic(ctx):
+    with ctx.lcd(settings.SRC_DIR):
+        ctx.local("python2.6 ./vendor/src/schematic/schematic migrations")
+
+
+@task
+def install_cron(ctx):
+    with ctx.lcd(settings.SRC_DIR):
+        ctx.local("python2.6 ./scripts/crontab/gen-crons.py -k %s -u apache > /etc/cron.d/.%s" %
+                  (settings.WWW_DIR, settings.CRON_NAME))
+        ctx.local("mv /etc/cron.d/.%s /etc/cron.d/%s" % (settings.CRON_NAME, settings.CRON_NAME))
+
+
+@task
+def update_sumo(ctx, tag):
+    """Do typical sumo update"""
+    update_code(tag)
+    update_locales()
+    schematic()

+from django.conf import settings
+from django.core.cache import parse_backend_uri
+
+from redis import Redis
+
+
+class RedisError(Exception):
+    """An error with the redis configuration or connnection."""
+
+
+def redis_client(name):
+    """Get a Redis client.
+
+    Uses the name argument to lookup the connection string in the
+    settings.REDIS_BACKEND dict.
+    """
+    if name not in settings.REDIS_BACKENDS:
+        raise RedisError(
+            '{k} is not defined in settings.REDIS_BACKENDS'.format(k=name))
+
+    uri = settings.REDIS_BACKENDS[name]
+    _, server, params = parse_backend_uri(uri)
+    db = params.pop('db', 1)
+    try:
+        db = int(db)
+    except (ValueError, TypeError):
+        db = 1
+    try:
+        socket_timeout = float(params.pop('socket_timeout'))
+    except (KeyError, ValueError):
+        socket_timeout = None
+    password = params.pop('password', None)
+    if ':' in server:
+        host, port = server.split(':')
+        try:
+            port = int(port)
+        except (ValueError, TypeError):
+            port = 6379
+    else:
+        host = server
+        port = 6379
+    return Redis(host=host, port=port, db=db, password=password,

To be future-proof we're going to need to set this up slightly differently. Something like

``` python
class Setting(ModelBase):
    user = models.OneToOneField(User)
    name = models.CharField()

```

review_comments.body:
So, bleach is probably not the right choice here, for a couple reasons.
- HTML sanitizing is generally something that should be done at, or closer to, output. We sanitize the wiki content before we stick it into `Document.html` because that's a caching mechanism to keep the pre-rendered HTML around. But in general, we don't know that the destination is HTML, so saving content sanitized for a specific output doesn't make sense. Keeping HTML sanitization closer to output also keeps things consistent for security reviewers.
- We only need to use `bleach.clean` if we _want_ to allow a subset of HTML. That isn't something we should generally assume: if we find a case where that _is_ necessary, we should be explicit about it, since we'll have to use `|safe` to render that, anyway.
- Bleach doesn't actually _validate_ anything--it sanitizes it. Django is a bit weird, using `clean` for the name of the method from which you throw `ValidationError` but we're really talking about validation here. The next couple of lines _do_ validate the value for the select/radio type, but we also need to validate and coerce for the checkbox (boolean) type.

review_comments.body:
It would be interesting to do a little magic for coercing `value` into a boolean when we're talking about the `checkbox` type. A couple options are:
- _Really magic_--name the property `_value` and set `db_column='value'`, then make `value` a getter/setter with `property`.
- _Not so magic_, but kind of Java-ish--add `get_value()` and `set_value()` methods.

I kind of hate explicit getters and setters, so I lean toward the more magic version.
`{{ csrf() }}` isn't a block, no need to indent "inside" it.
What is this `{% with %}` block doing?
These should all be `{% elif %}` since these are mutually exclusive cases.
We might want to set the IDs a little more carefully, maybe something like `id_setting_{{ setting.name }}`, just so a setting doesn't end up with the same ID as a page element and get screwy CSS.
`{{ setting.name }}` (no space at the end the first time)

Going along with the coercion comments earlier, I think `1` and `0` are better values than `on` and `off`. Those can be cast to boolean (well, ints, which is close enough) with `int()`, instead of `value == 'on'`.
Also, spaces around the `==` operator. Here and a number of places below.
Indent a level inside `{% for %}` blocks.
